awd_titl_txt: I-Corps: Automated As-is Facade Modeling of High-rise Buildings Using Drones and Artificial Intelligence
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the development of a high-rise building façade inspection technology. The new techology is based on the development of an automated, high-rise building façade modeling technology that uses drones and artificial intelligence (AI) algorithms.  The application has financial promise because it addresses the deterioration of building infrastructure. The proposed project may improve building inspection, maintenance, renovation, and repair while also educating and training the next generation of skilled workers. 

This I-Corps project is based on the development of an automated, as-is, high-rise building façade modeling technology using drones and artificial intelligence (AI) algorithms. To begin, a drone with a spiral path is employed to capture building exterior images and photogrammetry is used to conduct 3D reconstructions and create mesh models for the scanned building façades. High-resolution façade orthoimages are generated from mesh models and pixelwise segmented by an AI model. A combined data augmentation strategy, including random flipping, rotation, resizing, perspective transformation and color adjustment, is utilized for model training with few labels. The developed technology may transform the way that high-rise building façades will be inspected.  Missing façade drawings may be reproduced for maintenance, renovation, and repair operations. This technology may improve communication among building owners, design firms, contractors, material suppliers, and financial institutions while speeding up the design, approval, finance, construction and inspection processes.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The market for façade inspection has been continuously growing due to the aging of buildings in the United States. Currently, there are thirteen cities having ordinances that require building owners/facility managers to conduct periodical façade inspections. The inspections are performed manually which results in shortfalls such as inaccuracy, missing blind spots, and unsafe. The objective of this NSF I-Corps project is to determine the possibility of the commercialization of drone-based façade inspection technology. After literature review and interviewing 175 professionals, the following conclusions are reached.

1)     The current façade inspection practices are unable to inspect blind spots of the building façade and to cover 100% of the façade area. In addition, an inspector does not feel safe even though equipment is used to access locations at a height.

2)     The current façade inspection procedure is time-consuming which often leads to making errors while generating inspection reports.

3)     With the increase of the demand of the building façade inspections, the building related industries have formed a consensus that advanced technologies such as drone and AI must be developed and implemented for the façade inspection operations.

4)     The interview results indicate that the building related industries have an expectation that using drones in façade inspection will address challenges in accuracy, blind spot inspection, and safety.

5)     The developed drone system must have not only the visual aid tool/equipment required for the inspection of the building façade but also the capability of touching the surface and performing tests if needed.

6)     The commercialization of drone technology for building façade inspection will depend on not only the advancement of drone and AI technologies but also the successful modifications of current city ordinances and ASTM standards (such as ASTM E2019 and E2270).

7)     A new liability insurance policy must be available in the market for a building inspection company to cover the potential damage that may be caused by a drone during the façade inspection operations.

8)     New training materials/courses must be created to train drone pilots for building façade inspection.

            The research team also makes the following recommendations on the development of the commercialization of drone and AI technologies for building façade inspection.

1)     The research team does not recommend that a start-up company specialized in using drone for building façade inspections should be established right way because of technical issues and government regulations.

2)     The immediate effort that should be taken is to research and develop a drone system with a robotic arm that has touch sensors and can function as a human hand. Therefore, this drone system will have the capability of touching the building facades and performing tests as required by ASTM standards.

3)     There is a need to work with the technical committees that have the responsibility to manage the ASTM standards. With the success of continuous research and development of the drone system, it is possible that the ASTM standards will be modified to accommodate the drone and AI technologies for building façade inspections.

4)     There is a need to work with cities to modify the current ordinances. As a result, drone-based façade inspections will be allowed by government regulations. If recommendations 2) and 3) are realized, it will be much easier for government agencies to modify the city ordinances.

5)     Finally, there is a need to work with the insurance industry to develop an affordable insurance policy used for drone-based façade inspections.
